author: Benny Royston
title: Russia and Ukraine both reject EBU Eurovision peace offer
text:
Julia Samoylova was to represent Russia (Picture: EPA) Russian broadcaster Channel One and the Ukrainian deputy Prime Minister have both rejected a proposal that could have allowed Julia Samoylova to compete at the 2017 Eurovision Song Contest.
Grace Jones and De La Soul will feature on Gorillaz next album Humanz The two countries are fighting a bitter public relations war after Russia annexed Crimea from Ukraine in 2015 and are locked in military conflict in East Ukraine, and Eurovision is fast becoming the latest battlefield between the two countries with Eurovision organisers struggling to find a peaceful solution.
The Russian entrant, selected internally to compete at the Eurovision Song Contest in the Ukrainian capital this May has been barred from entering the country after performing in Crimea, land annexed by Russia from Ukraine.
Read more here .

In an unprecedented move earlier today, the European Broadcasting Union, organisers of the Eurovision Song Contest, offered a proposal that would allow Russia’s Eurovision Song Contest entrant, Julia Samoylova, the opportunity to perform via a live Satellite link during the competition to avoid an escalating political fallout.
Read about the EBU proposal here .
The EBU’s offer would have seen Julia compete from Russia via a live satellite broadcast dropping into the main Eurovision event in real time; it would be the first time in 63 years that an entrant would compete without being seen on the Eurovision stage.
However Russia and Ukraine have quickly rejected the offer.
Despite being aware that their selection would be most likely banned from entering Ukraine, Russia’s Channel One state : ‘Channel One acted in full accordance with the rules of Eurovision and chose the participant of the Contest, which is registered by the EBU and she remains our contestant.
‘Claims against Julia Samoylova are not from the EBU. According to the rules of Eurovision, the broadcasting country should provide all participants “the opportunity to obtain an entry visa for the entire period of the event.” Thus, Yulia Samoilova’s refusal to enter the territory of Ukraine violates the rules of the Contest.
‘We consider the offer of distance participation strange and refuse it, because it certainly contradicts the very meaning of the event, whose strict rule is the live performance on the stage of Eurovision.’

This is the first time in the history of Eurovision that a competitor is registered with the security forces of the host country for having broken the law of their land. As such, Ukraine believes that it has every right to deny Samoylova entry to the country.
Ukraine’s Minister for Culture, Vyacheslav Kyrylenko, tweeted that ‘broadcasts containing individuals who are banned from Ukraine are not legal within Ukraine and as a result the EBU’s proposal would violate Ukrainian law‘ and said that Russia would be welcome at the Eurovision Song Contest if they select an ‘artist who has not broken Ukrainian law’.
The EBU has told Metro.co.uk: ‘ We are continuing our dialogue with the Ukrainian authorities with the ambition to have all artists present to perform in host city, Kyiv, which is, of course, our preferred option. 
‘However, in case the travel ban on Julia Samoylova is upheld, we have to investigate alternative options. We have made a proposal to Channel One for one such alternative, and if accepted will review how to conduct this as fairly as possible within the framework of the local laws of the host broadcaster.’ 
Ukraine’s entry is O. Torvald with the rock song, Time.

The statement from Russia’s Channel One goes on to attack Eurovision organisers for trying to find a solution, stating: ‘We believe that the European Broadcasting Union should not invent new rules for the Russian participant in 2017 and is able to hold a competition in accordance with its own rules.’
Last night Channel One stated that if Julia Samoylova is not allowed to enter Ukraine, Russia would refuse to broadcast the 2017 Eurovision Song Contest and she would become their entrant for 2018.

Claims on social media suggest that although Channel One did appreciate the EBU offer, they had already decided to boycott the event in Ukraine, giving Julia, wheelchair bound since childhood, a strong story to promote her entry in twelve months time.
The EBU have yet to make a statement after Russia’s rejection of the proposal but have previously stated : ‘We have to respect the local laws of the host country, however we are deeply disappointed in this decision as we feel it goes against both the spirit of the Contest.’
Russia’s outright rejection of the proposal would suggest that they will not be competing at or broadcasting this year’s Eurovision Song Contest, which is set to be one of the strongest ever in terms of music quality.
Amongst the favourites to win the 2017 Eurovision Song Contest are Italy with Francesco Gabanni and Bulgaria’s Kristian Kostov, who’s Beautiful Mess is now second favourite with the bookies.
